security_audit.summary: This is a meta-skill that defines usage protocols. It contains no executable code, no network calls, no file system access beyond reading skill documentation, and no data exfiltration capabilities. It's purely instructional content for AI behavior.

content.value_statement: Stop wasting time deciding which skills to use. This protocol eliminates guesswork by requiring skill checks before every action. You'll never miss the perfect skill again.
actual_capabilities: Enforces mandatory skill checking before any response
Provides decision flowchart for skill usage
Defines rigid vs flexible skill types
limitations: Does not contain executable skills itself
Only guides skill selection, not execution

use_cases.title: Standardize skill usage
use_cases.description: Ensure consistent skill application across all conversations by following a strict protocol.

use_cases.title: Eliminate skill guesswork
use_cases.description: Remove uncertainty about when to use skills with clear decision criteria and priority rules.

use_cases.title: Maximize skill effectiveness
use_cases.description: Never miss relevant skills by following the mandatory checking protocol before every task.

prompt_templates.title: Basic skill check
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to help with [task]. First, I'll check if any skills apply by reading relevant SKILL.md files from the skills directory.

prompt_templates.title: Multiple skills
prompt_templates.prompt: This involves [task type]. I'll start with process skills like brainstorming or debugging, then move to implementation skills.

prompt_templates.title: Skill uncertainty
prompt_templates.prompt: There's a chance this might relate to [skill area]. I'll read the skill file to check - even 1% probability means I must verify.

prompt_templates.title: Skill priority
prompt_templates.prompt: Multiple skills could apply here. I'll use process skills first to determine approach, then implementation skills for execution.

output_examples.input: Help me build a web app
output: Using brainstorming skill to plan web app architecture
Using frontend-design skill to create UI components
Using mcp-builder skill to set up project structure
Following skill checklists for each implementation step

best_practices: Always check skills before responding, even for simple questions
Read skill files completely - do not rely on memory
Announce skill usage to maintain transparency
Follow checklists when provided in skills
anti_patterns: Assuming you know what a skill does without reading it
Skipping skill checks for seemingly simple tasks
Adapting rigid skills away from their discipline
Responding before checking if skills apply

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with all AI platforms?
faq.answer: Yes, it works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. The protocol is platform-agnostic.

faq.question: What if no skills apply to my task?
faq.answer: The protocol requires checking even with 1% probability. If no skills fit, proceed normally.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with my existing skill system?
faq.answer: Yes, simply place skill directories in a skills/ folder and follow the reading protocol.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this protocol?
faq.answer: Yes, this is a read-only protocol that only accesses skill documentation files.

faq.question: What if the skill seems wrong for the situation?
faq.answer: Read it anyway. If it doesn't fit, you don't have to use it - but you must check first.

faq.question: How does this compare to other skill management approaches?
faq.answer: Unlike optional skill systems, this enforces mandatory checking to ensure nothing is missed.
